item.title: UIKonf 2018 Review
item.description:
tl;dr: A collection of my favorite presentations from UIKonf, an independent technical and community conference for iOS developers.

I had the great pleasure to attend UIKonf in Berlin, Germany last week. It was a single track conference over two days that had a great balance of technical, business, and socially positive presentations. I really enjoyed getting to meet and learn from some incredible people from around the world. Here are some of my favorite presentations:

Kamilah Taylor - Tired of the state of online conversations? üôàüôâüôä Let‚Äôs do something about it üí™

A fantastic look at how today‚Äôs social media platforms‚Äô internal business measures of success encourage the polarization, misinformation, and distrust we‚Äôre seeing in society. More importantly, what people are starting to do to fix these problems.

John Sundell - The Magic of UI Testing

Great advice on how to find the right balance between test coverage, utility, and speed.

Carola Nitz - Advanced Debugging Techniques

A deep dive on some (not widely known) tools and techniques for finding and fixing issues with UIs and performance.

Dave DeLong - The Laws of Magic

A brand new talk from Dave where he discusses 3 ‚Äúlaws‚Äù for building engaging experiences and apps.

Janina Kutyn - Improving Scrolling Performance through GPU Optimisation

An introduction to how device CPU and GPU work together to produce smooth UIs and how you can improve their collaboration for your app.

Vincent Garrigues - Scaling iOS, a story of technical debt, and how to get through it

A story about the unitended consquences of rewriting the SoundCloud app, what the team learned from this experience, and how they used what they learned to succeed.

The entire set of conference presentations are also available on YouTube.

item.title: Making Location Edits To Apple Maps
item.description:
tl;dr: Apple accepts location data additions and edits for Apple Maps via macOS Maps app.

As a traveler one of my favorite features about macOS Photos app is the map view that displays the location of each of my photos. I love how this helps me remember my past travels as well as provides inspiration for places I have yet to visit. Recently I imported some travel photos that did not have geolocation information needed to power the map display. In order to get these photos to display on the map I had to geocode each photo. While doing so I discovered several locations that Apple Maps didn‚Äôt currently have. macOS Photos‚Äôs map works just fine with raw latitude / longitude coordinates for the photos but Apple Maps is much richer for all of us to have the locations labeled. Thankfully Apple has a way to do this.

S√∏fartsmonumentet

One such location is the S√∏fartsmonumentet in Copenhagen, Denmark. It‚Äôs a memorial built after World War I and features the Greek goddess Nike. It is located near the more famous Little Mermaid statue on the harbor.

Adding The Location

The first thing to do is to find and then mark the location on the map. This is done via Control clicking on the point where the new location should appear.

Drop Pin

Marked Location

Access To Location Data Editor

From the new pin tap the Info button to display the information Popover. The ‚ÄúReport Issue‚Äù button is located at the bottom of the Popover and is what opens the location data editor.

Information Popover

Open Location Data Editor via Report Issue button

Create The Location Edits

From the location data editor sheet are options available for creating the location edits. In this case ‚ÄúAdd A Place‚Äù is selected and the subsequent step by step workflow is followed through to it‚Äôs conclusion‚Ä¶ Send to Apple!

Location Data Editor Sheet

Add Location Editor Final Step

Follow Up

Apple then usually takes about a week to review submissions and if they accept them then sends a notification to you via your Apple ID connected devices. From there I‚Äôve noticed that it usually takes another couple of weeks before the basemap is updated and shows the location.

Newly Added Location Popover

Newly Added Location On Basemap

Happy Mapping!

item.title: Update site design
item.description:
Today I‚Äôm releasing an updated design to my Web site. This new design provides a cleaner and more consistent UI design while also making it easier to find content by tag as well as share it via the various platforms.

Having a Jekyll powered Web site made this process much easier as it has an amazing community of people and tools surrounding it. Thanks to this communinty I was able to find a new theme, Kasper, improved SEO support via the Jekyll-SEO plugin, and most importantly a wealth of information on the Web from other people to help learn how to customize things to my exact needs. Thanks also to GitHub Pages for continuing to host this site.

item.title: The Economist - "Not all roads lead to Google Maps"
item.description:
This past week The Economist published an article, ‚ÄúThe battle for territory in digital cartography‚Äù by Hal Hodson, discussing how companies like Mapbox and Mapillary are using community powered data from OpenStreetMap, crowdsourced imagery, and anonymous real time GPS location data gathering from smartphones to compete with the likes of Google in the quest to develop autonomous vehicles.

Needless to say, I‚Äôm absolutely thrilled to see how my work at Mapbox, building the anonymous real time GPS location data gathering technology in the Mapbox iOS and Android SDKs, continues to power Mapbox‚Äôs business today (Directions, Mapbox Drive, Maps, etc) as well as set the company up for future success. In addition to this, two major things that I‚Äôm also very proud of in regards to this work are that fact the data is collected anonymously and that it‚Äôs shared openly. Unlike many other tech companies, Mapbox has no way to tie collected location data to specific and named people. This was done on purpose. This focus on privacy not only helps people feel safe using the technology, but also allows Mapbox to publish / donate this location data to OpenStreetMap so that everyone can benefit with the latest in map data collected from the real world.

item.title: New Web site
item.description:
I‚Äôm excited to launch the next interation of my personal Web site today. It brings back complete control over the content and design which will allow me to hopefully produce richer and more useful content. I‚Äôve also ported my site‚Äôs previous posts going back to 2012 so everything can be found on the same site. I hope you enjoy it as much as I have creating it.

For those curious about the technical specs, it‚Äôs static site built using Jekyll and a self customized version of the minima theme. Finally, it‚Äôs hosted on GitHub Pages.

item.title: Mapbox Badgers
item.description:
Come join us next week at Science Hall on the University of Wisconsin-Madison campus as I team up my fellow Mapbox Badger alums and friends to present a hands-on workshop about working with open source geography tools. We‚Äôll be covering a range of topics from OpenStreetMap, Javascript and the Web, building Mobile apps, and working with PostGIS. Please bring questions and a laptop. I look forward to seeing you there!

On Wisconsin!

item.title: Making a Travel Map Using Mapbox Studio
item.description:
Making a travel map using Mapbox Studio is incredibly fun and surprisingly quick to do. I was able to create this map in less than 2 hours this afternoon by tweaking the stock Mapbox Dark style to remove visual clutter (Roads, City Names, Buildings, etc). From there I uploaded a GeoJSON file that contained the US States outlines and names. To finish it off I used the built it Data Filter tool to select the states that I‚Äôve visited in order to color them blue. To explore the map yourself it‚Äôs availalble at:

http://bleege.github.io/statesvisited/

If you‚Äôre interested in making your own maps like this checkout the ‚ÄúMake a choropleth map with Mapbox part 1: create a style with Mapbox Studio‚Äù step by step tutorial. It provides a great intoduction to the power and simplicity of the Mapbox Studio platform.

Happy Mapping!

item.title: Hey Mapbox How Do I Get To...
item.description: Earlier this month we released Android wrapper libraries for the Mapbox Geocoding and Directions API services to make adding Geocoding and Directions in your Android apps much easier. Naturally I wanted to do just that so I built a demo app called Go Where I Say that uses Android‚Äôs stock Speech To Text API to generate Directions based on voice commands. Did I mention that Google Play Services is NOT required? In other words it‚Äôs not only possible but it‚Äôs super easy to ask Mapbox for AND get directions to locations by using your voice inside your own apps without having to (rely on or) say ‚ÄúHey Siri‚Äù or ‚ÄúOk Google‚Äù. Checkout out the source code to see for yourself how to add this to your own apps.

item.title: I'm So Pumped to be Back in the Mapbox Garage
item.description: I‚Äôm so pumped to be back in the @mapbox Garage this week! (at Mapbox)

item.title: My First Revolution On The Mapbox Rocket Ship
item.description:
This past week I was excited to celebrate my first anniversary as a full time member of Mapbox! It‚Äôs been a fantastic experience where I‚Äôve been able to learn many new things and gotten to explore cities that I previously hadn‚Äôt spent much time in. My favorite part by far though has been getting to meet and more importantly getting to know a great group of people. This is simulateously the most empathetic, good humored, and smartest group of people that I‚Äôve ever worked with. It‚Äôs the combination of these traits that makes possible what we have been able to achieve together.

Speaking of which, it‚Äôs hard to believe but in just this one year we:

  • Built and released mobile vector mapping SDKs for iOS and Android
  • Released Mapbox Studio for WYSIWYG vector map styling and design
  • Grew the mobile team from 3 to 8 people
  • Partnered with Twitter on Twitter Fabric
  • Partnered with NVIDIA to use the Mapbox Android SDK in their DRIVE PX 2 platform announced at CES 2016
  • Supported Nepal Earthqauke Relief crisis mapping and fundraising

All in all, it couldn‚Äôt have gone better from my perspective. I‚Äôm incredibly grateful to be part of this team and to the people who helped get me here.

I can‚Äôt wait to see what we do together this year!
